'''Charlie Spand''' was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] and [[boogie-woogie]] [[pianist]] and [[singing|singer]], noted for his barrelhouse style. Spand was deemed one of the most influential piano players of the 1920s.<ref name="Yazoo">{{cite web |url=http://www.yazoorecords.com/2062.htm |title=Dreaming The Blues: The Best of Charlie Spand|author=|publisher=Yazoorecords.com |accessdate=October 25, 2010}}</ref> Little is known of his life outside of music, and his total [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] comprise only thirty-three (33) tracks.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
There is speculation about his place of birth. [[Allmusic]] stated that some claim Spand arrived in Elljay, [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]],<ref name="AMG 2"/> whilst his self-penned track, "Alabama Blues," had a reference to his birth in that part of the country.  Various blues historians also cited Spand's songs, "Levee Camp Man" and "Mississippi Blues," as evidence of connections there.<ref name="AMG"/>

More certain is that Spand, along with others such as [[William Ezell]],<ref name="Oliver">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Oliver
| year= 1997
| title= The Story of the Blues
| edition= New
| publisher= Northeastern University Press 
| location= Boston, Massachusetts
| isbn= 1-55553-354-X
| page= 89}}</ref> was one of those boogie-woogie pianists who, in the 1920s, performed on Brady Street and Hastings Street in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. In 1929, Spand relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], where he met and began performing alongside [[Blind Blake]]. Spand recorded twenty five songs for [[Paramount Records]] between June 1929 and September 1931.  The tracks were variously recorded in [[Richmond, Indiana]], Chicago, and [[Grafton, Wisconsin]]. From the 1929 Richmond recording sessions, were seven songs which had [[guitar]] accompaniment to Spand's piano playing and singing.  Most of these were directly attributed to Blake.  During Spand's most notable recording, he and Blake had a small conversation during the making of "Hastings Street."<ref name="AMG 2"/><ref name="Russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X
| page= 198}}</ref> Another such [[duet (music)|duet]] occurred on "Moanin' the Blues."<ref name="AMG"/>
 
After a gap in his recording career, in June 1940 Spand recorded what turned out to be his final eight tracks, this time for [[Okeh Records]].<ref name="AMG 2"/> These were made in [[Chicago]], when Spand was backed by [[Ernest Lawlers|Little Son Joe]] and [[Big Bill Broonzy]]. However, after these recordings were made, no further reference to Spand can be located.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=charlie-spand-p34608/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Charlie Spand |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 25, 2010}}</ref>

In 1992, [[Document Records]] issued ''The Complete Paramounts (1929-1931)''. [[Yazoo Records]]' ''Dreaming the Blues: The Best of Charlie Spand'' (2002) had enhanced sound quality, but without the chronological track order favored by Testament.<ref name="AMG 2">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=dreaming-the-blues-the-best-of-charlie-spand-r566546/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Dreaming the Blues: The Best of Charlie Spand |author= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 25, 2010}}</ref>

Spand's track "Back to the Woods" has been recorded by [[Kokomo Arnold]], Joan Crane and [[Rory Block]], while [[Josh White]] recorded his "Good Gal."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/charlie-spand-mn0000808133/songs |title=Charlie Spand | Songs |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
